title: 109_hr510
content: The Act may be cited as the "Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2005" and references amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965. It includes provisions for the Javits Fellowship Program. The Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2005 includes amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965, such as allowing fellowship recipients to interrupt study for military service or personal/family illness. It also ensures diversity in fellowship allocations. The Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2005 includes amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965, allowing fellowship recipients to interrupt study for military service or personal/family illness. It also ensures diversity in fellowship allocations by stipulating that the institution of higher education receiving the grant must be eligible under title III or V of the Act. Stipends for fellowship recipients have been adjusted, with changes to the years covered, the discretion in setting stipend amounts, and the renaming of the program to the Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program. The Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2005 includes amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965, allowing fellowship recipients to interrupt study for military service or personal/family illness. The institutional allowance for fellowship recipients is adjusted annually based on inflation. Authorization of appropriations is updated to fiscal year 2006 and the following five fiscal years. SEC. 3. GRADUATE ASSISTANCE IN AREAS OF NATIONAL NEED. The Secretary shall establish a priority for grants to prepare individuals for the professoriate who will train teachers in math, science, special education, and limited English proficiency. Grants will offer program assistance and graduate fellowships for post-baccalaureate teacher study. The Secretary prioritizes grants for post-baccalaureate teacher study in math, science, special education, and English language proficiency. Grants support dissertation research in these fields. Collaboration is required for certain applications. In the case of an application for a grant in education or teacher preparation, collaboration with departments in all content areas is required to ensure successful training in teaching and content. Amendments are made to stipends and additional assistance programs. Amendments are made to various sections of the education grant program, including changing the fiscal year from 1999-2000 to 2006-2007, authorizing appropriations for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years, and making technical corrections to specific sections. Amendments are made to the education grant program, including changes to the fiscal year and authorizing appropriations for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years. Additionally, technical corrections are made to specific sections. Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program is established. Amendments are made to the education grant program, including the establishment of the Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program. This includes preparing students for law school, developing analytical skills, and awarding Thurgood Marshall Fellowships to eligible law school students. Amendments to the education grant program include establishing the Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program, providing services in analytical skills and study methods, extending authorization of appropriations until 2006, and repealing subsection (e) of section 731. SEC. 5. FUND FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF POSTSECONDARY EDUCATION. The amendment to Section 741(a) of the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education focuses on encouraging reform, innovation, and educational opportunities for all postsecondary students, especially non-traditional and those seeking academic credit through distance education programs. The amendment to Section 744 of the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education includes institutional reforms to expand opportunities for entering postsecondary institutions and pursuing tailored programs of study. It also emphasizes international cooperation, academic program establishment, and support for teaching traditional American history. The amendment to Section 744 of the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education focuses on supporting programs for institutions of higher education to collaborate with private and civic organizations to address community issues like economic development, education, healthcare, and workforce preparation. The amendment to Section 745 authorizes $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2006 and necessary sums for the following 5 years to support programs for institutions of higher education collaborating with organizations on community issues like healthcare, self-sufficiency, and workforce preparation. SEC. 6. URBAN COMMUNITY SERVICE is repealed. SEC. 7. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS TO ENSURE STUDENTS WITH DISABILITIES RECEIVE A QUALITY HIGHER EDUCATION. Section 762(a) is amended to serve all students with disabilities, replacing "students with learning disabilities" with "students with disabilities." Section 762(b)(2) is amended to include activities for improving retention and completion for students with disabilities, as well as developing effective transition practices for their smooth transition from high school. The amendment to Section 762(a) expands its scope to include all students with disabilities, not just those with learning disabilities. Section 762(b)(2) is also amended to focus on improving retention, completion, and transition practices for students with disabilities. Additionally, a new subparagraph (D) is added to address the development of distance learning methods to enhance access to higher education for students with disabilities. The amendment expands the scope to include all students with disabilities. Section 763 is amended to include a description of how institutions plan to address activities allowed under this part and replicate best practices for serving students with disabilities. Authorization of Appropriations in Section 765 is also amended. The scope of the amendment is expanded to include all students with disabilities, with changes made to sections 763 and 765 regarding funding and planning for activities to serve these students.
